intro.title: Would your employees benefit from DISC training?
intro.subtitle: Answer 12 quick questions to find out if DISC training would benefit your employees' communication and collaboration

items.text: Employees adapt their communication style based on who they are interacting with.
Employees are aware of how their behavior impacts others in the workplace.
Conflicts between employees are typically resolved constructively and respectfully.
Employees are comfortable giving and receiving feedback across personality differences.
Collaboration across departments or teams happens smoothly and without repeated misunderstandings.
Employees can clearly identify each other's work styles and preferences.
New team members quickly understand and integrate into existing communication dynamics.
Workplace disagreements are more often due to strategy differences than personality clashes.
Employees are self-aware and able to reflect on their own work and interpersonal style.
Employees proactively seek to understand coworkers who are very different from them.
The organization has a common vocabulary for discussing behavior and communication differences.
There is a shared understanding of how diverse behavioral styles contribute to team success.

needPercentage.label: not-needed
needPercentage.displayText: Employees consistently demonstrate strong behavioral alignment, adaptability, and self-awareness.

needPercentage.label: low
needPercentage.displayText: Employees generally align with best practices, showing good communication and collaboration habits.

needPercentage.label: medium
needPercentage.displayText: Behavioral alignment is inconsistent, with noticeable differences in communication and work styles among employees.

needPercentage.label: very
needPercentage.displayText: Employees often face misunderstandings or friction due to behavioral differences and lack of a shared framework.

needPercentage.label: critical
needPercentage.displayText: There is a widespread lack of alignment in behavior, communication, and collaboration practices among employees.

narrative.intro: Employees show a high degree of behavioral alignment across the organization. Interactions are smooth, respectful, and grounded in mutual understanding.
narrative.main_text: Communication styles are well-calibrated, and employees demonstrate consistent self-awareness in how they show up at work. Teams collaborate with ease, adapting naturally to different personalities and working preferences. Conflicts are rare and usually resolved constructively. Newcomers integrate quickly into established communication norms, and feedback flows in a healthy, balanced manner. This environment reflects a mature culture with well-established behavioral norms.
narrative.conclusion: Employees are already practicing what the training teaches, suggesting a solid behavioral foundation.

impact.title: Impact
impact.description: This strong behavioral alignment likely contributes the following:
points: High team cohesion
Reduced interpersonal conflict
Faster onboarding and team integration
Strong psychological safety

Create internal content that reinforces DISC principles across teams

narrative.intro: Employees generally align with behavioral best practices, with only minor inconsistencies. Most teams function well in day-to-day collaboration.
narrative.main_text: Communication across the organization tends to be respectful and productive, with a shared willingness to understand different working styles. While most interactions are smooth, some employees may still rely on their default behavior under pressure, creating occasional friction. These moments are typically managed informally, but they point to opportunities for deeper behavioral alignment. Team leads often play a key role in smoothing over misunderstandings, and informal norms have developed over time. With more structure, the organization could turn good habits into great ones.
narrative.conclusion: Employees are on the right track but would benefit from structured reinforcement.

impact.title: Impact
impact.description: This partial alignment likely contributes the following:
points: Generally smooth collaboration
Occasional interpersonal friction
Slower integration of new team members
Minor miscommunications in cross-team work

next_steps.title: Next Steps
next_steps.description: While alignment is strong, consider this:
points: Offer targeted DiSCover Work sessions for selected teams
Integrate DISC concepts into leadership development programs
Provide optional behavioral coaching to support team leads
Use DISC data to inform feedback and performance conversations

narrative.intro: Behavioral alignment exists in parts of the organization but is not consistent across all teams. Different approaches to communication and collaboration are creating uneven experiences.
narrative.main_text: Some employees are highly self-aware and adapt their behavior well, while others rely heavily on their natural style, especially in stressful or ambiguous situations. This leads to communication gaps, missed signals, and occasional team friction. While employees often have good intentions, they may lack the tools or shared vocabulary to navigate personality differences effectively. Without a unifying behavioral framework, small misunderstandings can escalate or be left unresolved. These inconsistencies can erode trust and impact cross-functional collaboration.
narrative.conclusion: The organization would benefit from a shared model that helps normalize and navigate different behavioral styles.

impact.title: Impact
impact.description: This inconsistency likely contributes the following:
points: Mixed collaboration quality
Confusion around feedback and intent
Hesitancy in giving or receiving input
Misaligned work expectations between employees

next_steps.title: Next Steps

points: Schedule DiSCover Work workshops for cross-functional teams

Run follow-up sessions to reinforce DISC language and applications

narrative.intro: Employees frequently experience challenges in working together due to behavioral differences. There is no consistent approach to communication or collaboration.
narrative.main_text: Misunderstandings and misinterpretations are common, particularly in high-stakes or cross-departmental contexts. Feedback may be avoided or poorly received, and teams struggle to build the psychological safety needed for innovation and performance. Managers often act as buffers, but without a shared framework, they are left to navigate issues reactively. Employees may default to siloed behavior or withdraw from collaboration rather than work through interpersonal tensions. These dynamics impact productivity, morale, and speed of execution.
narrative.conclusion: A clear intervention is needed to create shared understanding and rebuild trust within and between teams.

impact.title: Impact
impact.description: This behavioral gap likely contributes the following:
points: Frequent misunderstandings or passive conflict
Delayed decision-making and feedback loops
Lack of trust or psychological safety
Reduced team performance and innovation

next_steps.title: Next Steps

Pair training with coaching for key influencers or managers

Introduce DISC in onboarding and performance frameworks

narrative.intro: There is widespread behavioral misalignment, and communication across the organization lacks cohesion. Employees are often left to navigate collaboration without support.
narrative.main_text: Teams are frequently in conflict or operating in silos, and interactions are marked by misunderstandings, defensiveness, or disengagement. Feedback rarely flows smoothly, and employees often avoid tough conversations. New hires struggle to integrate, and cultural fragmentation is evident across departments. In the absence of a common framework, even well-intentioned collaboration becomes challenging. This environment creates significant friction and slows down collective progress.
narrative.conclusion: An urgent, organization-wide intervention is needed to restore alignment and support effective teamwork.

impact.title: Impact
impact.description: This misalignment likely contributes the following:
points: High conflict frequency or avoidance
Low employee morale and engagement
Lack of shared accountability
Poor onboarding experiences and slow team formation
